text: (bright music)
- Hi, Scott. First of all,
thanks for being here,
and very excited to talk about
all things related to golf and Gen AI.
So with that, we started with,

I'm sure most of our viewers
have heard of PGA Tour,

so you don't need to
do one-on-one on that,
but can you tell us a little more

about your organization and
your role at the company?
- Sure, sure. Well, it's great to be here.

Thank you for taking this
time to talk with me, Swami.
I really appreciate it.

So, PGA Tour is a very
exciting organization.

We are responsible for
the week in and week out

golf org, golf events that
happen all around the world.
So it's just on the PG tour alone,
we have about 35 events that we do.
We also run four other tours here as well.

So many weeks we have
five, six events going on
all around the world.
And so it's a very busy,

very busy time for us here
in the middle of the summer
with our events going on.

I run, oversee all of the
PGA Tours digital platforms,

as well as all the tours,
broadcast technologies.

I've been here at the PGA
Tour now for almost 19 years.
It'll be 19 years in September.

So, and I've had the
pleasure, and the opportunity,

and the privilege to be
able to take the tour
all the way from just a website in 2005,

now to generative AI.
(Swami laughs)

So it's, it's been, it's
been an exciting 19 years.

- That's awesome. Talking
about your journey,
now, let's talk about PGA Tour's journey.

You have always been
innovating with AI and ML,

so maybe can you share
a little bit like what

did the Tour's journey
look like with AI and ML,
and now with Journey AI?
- Sure. Sure. So we've been using AI
and ML for many, many years,
probably for at least the past 10 years.

It's played a role in a lot
of our content creation,
and a lot of the ways that we address
scoring around the organization.
So our scoring, our shot link system,

which is used to capture
all of the ball flight,

and the scores for all the
players across the PGA Tour,

at every event has been
using machine learning for,
for the, almost its entire history.

And so that is kind of really
where it started for us.
And then as we got into, you know,
the last seven, eight years as we
got into using machine learning on the
content side of the business,

we use machine learning tools
to clip all of our highlights.

And in doing so, we were
able to actually triple
the number of highlights

that we used coming through
a tool set by WSC Sports.
We have also been using tools to generate,

help us generate stories for
our players throughout the day
after an event is, after player's done.
We, we have, you know,

typical PGA Tour event has
anywhere from 80 to 154 players,
depending on the event.
And generating a story,
or content for every one of those players
is not something we can do with staff.
So it's something that we've been using

machine learning to do
after the player is done,
so that whether it's generating statistics

for our players, or generating
the stories directly.

And then, you know,
we've become very excited

about generative AI
over the last 24 months,
as we've seen the platforms emerge,

and really begin to see how
we can use generative AI
to create all kinds of new experiences

for our fans, and
efficiencies for our staff
to create compelling experiences.
Because ultimately our goal here

is to serve our players,
to serve our events,

and to bring our fans
closer to our players,
and the historic courses that we play on,
and week in and week out.
And we believe generative AI
is gonna be the next step in doing that.
- That's awesome. Maybe can you share
some of the challenges you are trying
to solve for with Gen AI,
and what are some of the examples

or solutions that you were
actually launch so far?
- Sure. So for us, with generative AI,
a lot of it has to do right now with

how do we create personalized
experiences for our fans?

- Mm-hmm.
- Again, with a,
with a large field, you know,
people wanna follow their favorite player,
whether that's Rory Mcilroy or Tony Finau,
and they wanna be able to be kept
up-to-date on those players.

So right now what we're
working on is a series of tools
that will actually generate commentary

for your favorite players across
a number of our platforms.

So something that we expect
to have out later this year.

It'll essentially create
narratives around, you know,
Rory's entire round as he is playing,
and give context to it.
Right now we use,
we've used machine learning to generate,
you know, play by play.
So Rory hits a, you know, hits a drive,

or a shot into the green
at the tour championship
in Atlanta at East Lake,
and he gets within 10 feet of the hole.

But we can, we can generate
kind of the state, you know,

shot one, a hundred twenty
five yards to the green,
10 yard, or 10 feet left to the hole,
but that, that's all it would,
traditionally that you would see.
Now what we're trying to do

with generative AI is create
context around those shots.
So when Rory gets in that position,
he's 10 feet from the hole.
We wanna be able to do a number of things.

One is tell you, how often
does he make a 10 foot putt?
Does he make 20% of the time, right?

How often has he made a
10 foot putt on this hole

in the past when he is played
this event a number of times?
And then bring that shot

to you whether he is made
it in the past or not.
So we're looking at multimodal responses,
not only to give you textual information,

but to show you exactly
what he's done in the past.

And eventually what we'll
be doing is predicting,

through machine learning
and through generative AI,

predicting how important
this 10 foot shot is.
If he makes this 10 foot shot,
is he gonna win the FedEx Cup,
or is he gonna take the lead
in the tournament in round two?

You know, or what
position he's going to do.
So, and really begin to take that data
and present it in different voices.
Some of the things that we've worked with,

the generative AI, our
Innovation Center audits,
how do we project different tone?

So if you're comment, you know,
commentator, or an analyst,

if you want to hear it
from the point of view of,
you know, you're maybe,
maybe you're a 12 or 13-year-old fan,
you wanna hear it in the point-of-view
from a somebody who's new to golf.

- Yeah.
- How do you explain it
it in that case?
So we see there's a way to address a

number of things including
growing our audience.
- That's incredible actually.

I always found that the
application generative AI
in areas like sports makes the technology
even more relatable and accessible.

So it's really fascinating
what you're innovating with.

Now, I want to double
click one level deeper,

and say like, maybe can you
share a little bit details
on the solution you built using AWS,
so that others can understand
how to recreate such magical experience?
- Sure, sure. So for us,
it really started working with

the Generative AI Innovation
Center and that team,
and really understanding Bedrock.

We were one of the earliest
partners into Bedrock.
So we were learning how to use it,
and then what does it mean,

really it became obvious
for us for a couple reasons.
One is we had to get our data,
you hear hear us say data all the time,

but I like to say data
and content together

because often people don't
think of content as data.

And that's really what the
power of generative AI is,
is how do you prepare your data,
our shot link data over 20 years,

and then how do you take
content that we've created,
whether that's our media guides, you know,

30 plus years of media
guides that we have in PDFs,

or all the content that
we have on pgtour.com,

or you know, over our, our
media asset management system.

You know, having, you
know, many, many hours

of content stored in or
video content stored in it.

So those are the things that
we have available to us.
So how do you get that content ready?
How do you index it?
You know, what AWS tools are we gonna use,
like Kendra, to index all of that content,

and have it prepared so
that you can then begin
to make queries against it,
and use the generative AI tools.
And then begin to look at these tools

from the perspective of
what models are best for us.
You know, how do we do model evaluation?
What models might work best for a query

that is based on statistical
information and media guides,
versus one that might be better at,

at getting at the video
and creating and creating?
So how can we use Bedrock,
and what bedrock tools do we use
to do that model evaluation?
And then once we get through that,
the question became,
"Alright, how do you use,

"how do you build for
correctness and accuracy?"

Because correctness and
accuracy in sports is paramount.
We have to be right about, you know,

the percentage of putts
that Roy McElroy takes

from 10 feet to get
the ball into the hole.
So how do we build in tools and practices
for generative AI to make sure
that we have the correctness and accuracy?

And then if we're gonna
build things like chatbots

or virtual assistants, gotta
put guardrails in place, right?
So how do we put guardrails in place,
and red teaming in place,
and brand alignment in place as well too?
Because not only do we need to make sure

that we red team for
the obvious challenges
of toxicity and bias,
but how do we take,
make sure that the things
that are being generated are, you know,
within the brand of the PGA Tour,
and representative of our players.
And then how do we put it together
in an entertAIning experience, right?
How do we take all of that,
and then put it into existing tools
like our tour cast product,
which is our 3D digital twin,
and then suddenly be able to get,

provide commentary that
is personalized to the,
to the player, that person's following,
and eventually, like how do we get
that into multiple languages,
or multiple types of tone,

so people can actually customize
it the way they want to?
So each one of these steps
that we're taking were exploratory steps,
and then working with the
generative AI Innovation Center,

and the AWS teams, how do
we operationalize this,

- Right?
- Yeah. How do we continue
to make sure that what's being,

what's being generated
is accurate and correct?
How do we continuously test for that?

- Yeah.
- And make sure that
the accuracy is always at the
level that we want it to be at?
And so all of these steps are the steps

that we're now in the
middle of putting in place,
and getting ready to roll out a series.
Like the generated commentary will
come at the end of the year.
We will build, we are in the act

of building the first
generation of what I will be,
what I believe will be great tools
for our broadcast and production teams.

So an an example of that
is I wanna be able to give,

you know, our announcers on
ESPN Plus on PG Tour Live,
and our broadcast partners at CBS,
and NBC, and Golf Channel, if they want,
you know, five new talking points
after every shot is hit,
I want them to be able to go in and say,

"Look, we're gonna follow
these five players today,

"and after every shot
generate two or three

"talking points for me."
- Mm.

- So that I can then work
those in my commentary
to the broader audience, right?

- Yeah.
- And so those will help

us surface things that
we've never been able
to surface before in a tone or in a way
that I think will provide greater depth
of coverage for our events.

- Hmm. So you talked
about, you already started,
alluded to where you are hoping to go
beyond what is possible today with Gen AI,
like never before uncovered game insights.

So maybe it's a good
jumping off point to say

what else are you hoping to
do next with these things

in terms of, is it like more
game insight, or different?
Can you share a little bit more?
- Sure, sure. So a couple of other things,
a lot of what I talked about addresses
what our fans are doing.
Next, one of the things that we are
hoping to address is helping our players

understand their game and
how they're playing, right?
So creating a player agent that,

as a player like Rory
comes off the course,
and we can have that player agent

analyze his performance on
that round that day, and say,

"You know what? Based
on what you've told us
"about the way that you play your game,
"and how you wanna play on this course,

"here's what we've seen
in your tendencies today,

"and here's how your
statistics really played out

"over that round based
on what your plan was."

And so being able to give
the players, their coaches,

that ability to say, "Okay,
yeah, that makes sense.
"This is a thing that you look at."
Our players are, they use our apps,

and our websites to see how
they performed that day.
I wanna take that a step further,
and provide that analysis.
So that that would be one way of,
of helping our players.
Another way is just to help create
efficiencies for our staff.
You know, throughout the history
that we deal with in golf,
is a long and storied history.
The PGA Tour has, you know,
been around now since 1968,
and we have a huge depth of information
about how players have performed,
how courses have been a big part of that.
And so what we wanna be able to do is
we wanna be able to enable our staff
to get into that information
that is stored across ShotLink data,
that is stored across,

you know, that is stored
across our media guides,
that is stored across our agronomy notes,
and a number of other areas.
And so allow our staff to go in there
when they're writing stories to say,
"Oh, you know, tell me about
"how Rory performed at East Lake
"in his first event there 10 years ago."
And then let's compare that to

how Rory has performed
at East Lake in 2024.
And tell me what you see his
tendencies are and his differences are.

So providing, you know, context
that our staff may have,
because, you know, you hire a new staff,
they don't have that historical context.

- Yeah.
- And all like,
you know, they've had to dig into
media guides or ask longer tenured staff,
or, you know, things like that.

So these tools should be
able to help with that,
and help us drive deeper,

create a deeper set of
content for our fans.
- That's fascinating. Fascinating.
Oh, one final question.
As a technologist,
I mean who has really embraced not just

AI, ML historically, but
also innovating with Gen AI.

What is your advice for
others who are looking
to get started with Gen AI?

- Sure. I think what I've
learned is experimentation
and education are really at the forefront
of what you need to do right now.

- Yeah.
- Generative AI needs

to be handled a little
differently in every organization.
And the tools are evolving so quickly,

that you really need
to be at a place where
you're not only sitting and learning,
you know, from team members like the,

you know, the generative
AI innovation lab at AWS,

and AWS professional services
who we work with closely.
But you really need to be getting hands-on

experience with the tools,
because you need to,
you need to train models,
you need to train guardrails,

you need to teach these
models what it means
to work within the context
of the data and content in your business.
And that takes some time,

but I think it's gonna prove
very valuable for everybody.
So for us it's definitely been,
you know, experimentation and education.
- That's awesome. Great piece of advice.
Something that I tend to
say that internally a lot as well.
So really appreciate you sharing that.
Scott, thanks again for actually sharing
a great set of insights,

and your journey with
generative AI on PGA Tour.
Really enjoyed our chat.
- Great. Thank you so much, Swami.

Appreciate it.
- Thank you.
